questions.text:
Match the following ocular examination findings with their pathology.
  1. Wessely's immune ring
  2. Vossius ring 
  3. Arcus lipoides
  4. Kayser-Fleischer ring
questions.solution:
The correct match is as follows:

Image A Vossius ring
Image B  Arcus lipoides
Image C  Kayser-Fleischer ring
Image D  Wessely's immune ring

Vossius ring is a circular ring of faint or stippled opacity, seen on the anterior surface of the lens due to brown amorphous granules of pigment lying on the capsule of the lens. It is usually seen after blunt trauma to the eye and orbit. It usually has about the same diameter as the contracted pupil. The force of the blow drives the cornea and iris backwards, thus producing an impression of the iris on the lens as shown below. The resorption of the pigment results in discrete subcapsular opacities.

It is shown in the image below:

Arcus senilis (AS) or arcus lipoides/Gerontoxon.is usually an age-related lipid degeneration of the peripheral corneal that forms a light grey or bluish ring. It is caused by leakage of lipoproteins (phospholipids and cholesterol) from limbal capillaries into the corneal stroma. Characteristically it is separated from the margin by a narrow zone of comparatively clear cornea. It is the most common peripheral corneal opacity and is usually found in the elderly where it is considered a benign condition. When AS is found in patients less than 40 years old it is termed arcus juvenilis. It represents an increased risk for cardiovascular disease and warrants screening for an underlying lipid disorder.

Arcus senilis is shown in the image below:

Kayser-Fleischer ring: Intraocular deposition of copper is seen in Wilson's disease and would result in a KF ring/ Kayser-Fleischer ring on the cornea. A brownish-yellow zone is seen in the peripheral Descemet membrane of the cornea. Anterior capsular cataract, also known as a sunflower cataract may be seen in some patients. 

It is shown in the image below:

The Wessely's immune ring is formed by infiltrates of stroma in a circular fashion in fungal corneal ulcers. It is due to a type 3 hypersensitivity reaction (antigen-antibody complex).

The immune ring of Wessely can be made out as a deep stromal haze in a slit lamp. It occurs as a result of the deposition of antigen-antibody complexes in the stroma. Once deposited it draws the immune cells, inciting further inflammation.

The given image shows an ulcer in the cornea and the adjacent immune ring of Wessely.

questions.text:
A student is referred by the school nurse with complaints of recurrent headaches and inability to read from the classroom board. There is no diplopia. Examination shows a refractive error of -1D in the right eye and an error of -3D in the left eye. What is your diagnosis?

D - dioptre
questions.solution:
The history of defective vision and 2 different refractive errors of the eyes suggests a diagnosis of anisometropia.

Anisometropia occurs when the total refraction of both eyes are unequal. A difference of 1D in the two eyes causes a 2% difference in the size of retinal images formed. A difference up to 2.5D is well-tolerated, but beyond 4D cannot be tolerated. Anisometropia can occur as a combination of emmetropia, myopia, hypermetropia, and astigmatism.

It is diagnosed after retinoscopic examination and autorefractometry. 

Treatment includes the usage of spectacles (it can be tolerated up to a maximum difference of 4D), contact lenses, intraocular lenses (for uniocular aphakia), refractive corneal surgery, or refractive lens exchange methods (used in high degree anisometropia).

Other options: 

Option B: Aniseikonia occurs when the images that are projected to the visual cortex are abnormally unequal in size. A high degree of anisometropia can also cause anisekonia. However, here the student has a refractive difference of only 2D.

Option C: Irregular astigmatism is the irregular change of refractive power that occur in different meridians. Patients complain of polyopia (seeing multiple images), distortion of objects and defective vision. It is assosciated with corneal irregularities and keratoconus.

Option D: Emmetropia is defined as an optically normal eye where the parallel rays of light coming from infinity focuses at the retina with accomodation at rest.

questions.text:
From the given prescription of spectacles, which of the following are examples of simple, myopic with-the-rule astigmatism?
  1. -1DS with +2DC at 180o
  2. -1DS with +1DC at 90o
  3. +2DC at 90o
  4. -1DS with -1DC at 90o
  5. -1DC at 180o
questions.solution:
Among the above options, ii and v are the correct examples for simple myopic astigmatism with-the-rule.  

Simple myopic astigmatism is where the rays of light form two focal points one before the retina and one on the retina. When the two principal meridians of light rays are placed at right angles to one
another but the vertical meridian is more curved than the horizontal, it is called with-the-rule astigmatism. 

Options - 

A. -1D is the power of the sphere on the vertical and horizontal axis. With cylindrical correction of +2D at 180o, it acts along the vertical axis (since the cylindrical correction always acts in the axis perpendicular to it). Thus, the resultant is:

Power in the vertical axis = -1 plus +2 = +1D 

Power in the horizontal axis = -1D

This is an example of mixed astigmatism. 

 

B. -1D is the power of the sphere on the vertical and horizontal axis. Here, +1D correction of cylindrical acts horizontally. Thus, the resultant power in the:

Vertical axis = -1D

Horizontal axis = -1 plus +1 = 0

Since myopia has higher power than emmetropia, the power in the vertical axis is more than in the horizontal. Thus, this is an example of simple myopic with-the-rule astigmatism. 

 

C. +2DC power of the cylindrical indicates hypermetropia. 

D. Resultant power in the horizontal axis here is = -1 plus -1 = -2D

Vertical axis = -1D.

This is an example of a compound, myopic against-the-rule astigmatism. 

 

E. Here, the power of the cylindrical (-1DC) is seen only along one axis. Hence, it is simple myopic astigmatism. Since the power acts vertically, the vertical axis has more power than the horizontal one, following the with-the-rule mechanism.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female presented with acute loss of vision and metamorphopsia. There is a history of the positive scotoma. Fundal changes are given below. What will be the fundus fluorescein angiography finding?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the fundal image depicting focal fundal detachment are suggestive of central serous retinopathy. An enlarging inkblot pattern or smoke stack pattern is seen in FFA.

Central serous retinopathy refers to the spontaneous serous detachment of the neurosensory retina in the macular region. Recent studies implicate an abnormal choroidal circulation as the cause of CSR. 

Clinical features:

  • Retinal detachment - Sudden painless loss of vision
  • Relative positive scotoma
  • Micropsia
  • Metamorphopsia

Investigations:

  • Ophthalmoscopy - circular ring reflex present and foveal reflex absent
  • FFA - enlarging inkblot pattern or smoke stack pattern

Spontaneous resolution is seen in most cases and hence observation is enough. Steroids are contraindicated. The disease is usually self-limiting but may recur.

The image depicts fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA), showing an enlarging ink-blot pattern/enlarging dot sign, which is seen in central serous retinopathy (CSR).

Other options:

Option B- Petaloid appearance is seen in cystoid macular edema

Option C- Stars in the sky appearance is suggestive of drusen

Option D- Dual circulation is a pathognomonic feature of choroidal melanoma

questions.text: Identify step 3 in the given cataract surgery procedure.
questions.solution:
The picture illustrates extracapsular cataract extraction by the phacoemulsification method. Step 3 indicates hydro dissection.

Hydrodissection is the process of separating the capsule from the nucleus and cortex by injecting fluid between the two. This step is used in all extracapsular cataract extraction procedures and is mandatory in phacoemulsification and manual small incision cataract surgeries.

The steps involved in the cataract surgery are: 

  • Step 1 - small clear corneal incision 
  • Step 2 - continuous curvilinear capsulorhexis
  • Step 3 - hydro dissection, which also facilitates rotation and manipulation of the nucleus during emulsification of the lens
  • Step 4 - hydro delineation is done in some cases. This is done by injecting fluid between the nucleus and epinuclear lens substance. It aids in the separation of the cortex from the nucleus
  • Steps 5 and 6 - indicate the divide and conquer technique for the removal of the nucleus after phacoemulsification
  • Step 7 - removal of the cortical lens matter using an irrigation-aspiration technique
  • Step 8 - implantation of a foldable lens

Related Pearl: Different extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE) techniques

Conventional ECCE

  • Incision: 10 to 2 o'clock
  • Anterior capsulotomy
    • Can opener’s technique
    • Envelope technique
    • Continuous circular capsulorrhexis

Manual SICS

  • Incision: 4-6 mm
  • A self-sealing sclerocorneal tunnel incision is made.

Phacoemulsification

  • Incision:1.5–2.4 mm
  • Phacoprobe and foldable IOL is used
  • Sutureless surgery is possible with self-sealing sclerocorneal tunnel or clear corneal incision.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient needs to undergo cataract surgery. Before initiating the surgery, the following procedure is performed. What is the most common complication seen in the procedure?
questions.solution:
The most common complication seen in the procedure of retrobulbar block is retrobulbar haemorrhage.

The image shown above depicts the technique of retrobulbar block which is a regional anaesthesia technique used in ophthalmic surgery. It involves the injection of a local anaesthetic into the extraocular muscle cone. The needle penetrates the lower lid at the junction of the middle and lateral one-third of the orbit.

Related Pearl: Complications and contraindications of retrobulbar block

Complications:

  • Retrobulbar hemorrhage (most common complication)
  • Subconjunctival hemorrhage
  • Proptosis
  • Perforation of the globe
  • Optic nerve atrophy
  • Oculocardiac reflex
  • Accidental intravascular injection of the local anesthetic
  • Trigeminal nerve block
  • Respiratory arrest
  • Acute neurogenic pulmonary edema (rarely)

Contraindications:

  • Bleeding disorders (because of the risk of retrobulbar hemorrhage)
  • High myopia (if the axial length is greater than 25 mm, then sclera would be thin which could increase the risk of globe perforation)
  • Open eye injury or penetrating eye injury: injection of local anesthetic behind the globe could increase the intraocular pressure which could lead to extrusion of the orbital contents.

questions.text: The clinical distinction between a cavernous sinus syndrome and an orbital apex syndrome is best made by the dysfunction of which structure?
questions.solution:
The clinical distinction between a cavernous sinus syndrome and an orbital apex syndrome is made by the dysfunction of the optic nerve (marked as "A")

The optic nerve passes through the optic canal and does not enter the cavernous sinus. Patients with orbital apex syndrome manifest complete ophthalmoplegia, ptosis, decreased corneal sensation, and vision loss. They usually develop optic nerve signs such as relative afferent pupillary defect. Proptosis is often present, but patients do not always complain of pain.

Cavernous sinus syndrome (CSS) is a rare condition characterized by ophthalmoplegia, proptosis, ocular and conjunctival congestion, trigeminal sensory loss, and Horner’s syndrome. These signs and symptoms result from the involvement of the cranial nerves passing through the cavernous sinus. The cavernous sinus syndrome affects III, IV, V, and VI cranial nerves. The III, IV, V cranial nerves pass in relation to the lateral wall of the cavernous sinus. VI cranial nerve passes through the cavernous sinus. The cavernous sinus syndrome is a distinctive and frequently life-threatening disorder.

Orbital apex syndrome includes the following:

  • Pain, typically labelled as retro-orbital ache
  • Sensory loss/disturbances in the distribution of the ophthalmic division of the 5th cranial nerve
  • Ipsilateral ophthalmoplegia due to the involvement of the 3rd, 4th, and 6th cranial nerve involvement
  • Ptosis, due to 3rd nerve paralysis
  • Features of optic nerve involvement, i.e., early visual loss and afferent pupillary defect.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child with frequent eye discomfort, pain and watering was diagnosed with corneal dystrophy. The histological section stained with Masson's trichrome reveals the presence of hyaline protein in the stroma. Identify the diagnosis.
questions.solution:
The diagnosis of a 3-year-old with ocular symptoms due to corneal dystrophy with histological sections showing the presence of hyaline protein in the stroma is Granular dystrophy.

The corneal dystrophies are a group of progressive, usually bilateral, variable corneal opacifying disorders, many of which are associated with decreased vision and discomfort. Based on the layers of the cornea involved, they are classified into,

  • Epithelial
  • Bowman layer
  • Stroma
  • Descemet membrane and
  • Endothelial dystrophies

Granular corneal dystrophy belongs to the stromal dystrophy of the cornea. It is of autosomal dominant inheritance and is caused by a defect in the TGFB1 gene.

In granular corneal dystrophy, opacities form due to the abnormal accumulation of hyaline protein, assuming a discrete granular form and subsequently coalescing into various irregular shapes. The cornea between the opacities and the peripheral cornea remains clear. The condition is characterised by milky granular hyaline deposits in the anterior stroma.

Early symptoms may involve light sensitivity, glare, ocular discomfort, pain, and watering. As opacification progresses with age, visual acuity decreases.

The following image shows numerous irregularly shaped discrete crumb-like corneal opacities of Granular dystrophy.

 

Dystrophy Slit lamp appearance Microscopy
Granular dystrophy Bread-crumb-like deposits in the stroma Amorphous hyaline deposits staining bright red with Masson trichrome 
Lattice dystrophy 'Glass-like' filamentous lesions Exhibits apple green birefringence with congo red stain
Macular dystrophy Greyish white spots in the stroma Acid mucopolysaccharidosis (GAGs) deposits stain with Alcian blue
Fuchs endothelial dystrophy "Beaten metal" appearance Wart-like excrescences (corneal guttae) on Descemet membrane

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman was brought by her son to an eye clinic with complaints of diminished vision in her left eye. An image of her eye is shown below. What is the most likely type of corneal opacity in this patient?
questions.solution:
The corneal opacity shown in the given image is most likely a leucomatous type of corneal opacity.

The above clinical vignette and image showing a dense white opacity, and scarring of more than half of the stroma is characteristic of leucomatous corneal opacity. 

Corneal opacities can be graded, depending on their density, as:

  • Nebular corneal opacities or nebula, where only slight opacification of the cornea occurs due to scarring. It is possible to observe the iris clearly through this type of opacity.
  • Macular corneal opacities or macula, which is described as a semi-dense opacity that can be seen with proper illumination. This occurs subsequent to scarring that spans about half the corneal stroma. The iris and pupillary margins are usually visible.
  • Leucomatous corneal opacities or leucoma simplex, which is a white scar that is easily seen just by looking at the eye. It occurs due to scarring of more than half of the corneal stroma.
  • Adherent leucoma is observed when there is perforation and subsequent healing of the cornea, but with the incarceration of the iris in it.

Secondary changes in corneal opacity which may be seen in long-standing cases include hyaline degeneration, calcareous degeneration, pigmentation and atheromatous ulceration.

The treatment depends upon the type of opacity. Keratoplasty is the treatment of choice in leucomatous corneal opacities. Optical iridectomy may be performed in cases with central adherent leucomas. Phototherapeutic keratectomy (PTK) performed with excimer laser is useful only in superficial (nebular) corneal opacities.

Corneal tattooing is a treatment option in patients with corneal opacities with firm scarring and poor vision. It only improves cosmetic appearance.

Related Pearl: Corneal Opacities

Corneal opacity is formed when Bowman's layer (+/- deeper layer) is damaged.

Nebular opacity

  • Faint white
  • Only Bowman's layer is involved
  • Causes more visual handicap than macular opacity due to the scattering of light

Macular opacity

  • White in color
  • Bowman's layer + Half of stromal thickness involved

Leucoma

  • White and opaque
  • BM + half or more than half stromal thickness involved

Image: Leucomatous corneal opacity

questions.text: A male patient presented with painless, hard swelling of the lower eyelid that has been progressing in size. Examination revealed the following finding. What is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presentation of a progressive, hard, painless swelling is due to a probable diagnosis of chalazion.

Chalazion is a chronic and non-infective lipogranulamatous lesion that arises from the Meibomian glands (otherwise known as tarsal/meibomian cyst). It is the most common lid swelling seen.

A very small, soft, and recent chalazion only requires conservative management with hot compresses and topical antibiotic drops. Incision and curettage is the more conventional method of managing a chalazion. The contents are curetted out using a chalazion scoop. Intralesional steroids such as triamcinolone are preferred for chalazions which are located where the risk of surgical damage is greater (near structures such as lacrimal punctum).

A chalazion may become infected and form a hordeolum internum. Also, a recurrently forming chalazion should be biopsied to rule out meibomian gland adenocarcinoma (a form of sebaceous cell carcinoma).

Other options: 

Option A: Hordeolum externum is the suppurative inflammation of the gland of Zeis. It is hard and painful, and there is a visible pus point on the lid margin.

questions.solution:
The image shows a pachymeter used to measure corneal thickness. The corneal thickness indirectly reflects endothelial function. Ultrasonic pachymeters are more reliable than optical pachymeters.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the condition shown in the image below?

choices.text: Treatment of larger defects requires skin grafts.
Treacher Collins syndrome is associated with coloboma of eyelid.
It usually occurs near the temporal side

questions.solution:
The given image shows a coloboma of the upper eyelid. Option D is the false statement as it usually occurs near the nasal side and not the temporal side.

Coloboma of the eyelid is a partial or full-thickness eyelid defect. It more frequently involves the upper lid (Option B) than the lower lid and usually occurs on the nasal side. It occurs when eyelid development is incomplete, due to failure of migration of lid ectoderm to fuse with the lid folds.

Upper-lid colobomas occur at the junction of the middle and inner thirds and have a relatively strong association with cryptophthalmos, facial abnormalities, and Goldenhar syndrome. (Cryptophthalmos is a congenital anomaly in which the eyelids are absent, replaced by a continuous layer of skin). Lower lid colobomas occur at the junction of the middle and outer thirds and are frequently associated with systemic conditions. 

Treacher Collins syndrome is characterized by malformations in the derivatives of first and second branchial arches, primarily mandibular and ear anomalies. Lower eyelid coloboma (Option C) is a feature of this syndrome along with slanted palpebral apertures, cataracts, microphthalmos, and lacrimal atresia. 

Small defects can be managed by primary closure, while large defects require skin grafts (Option A) and rotation flaps.

questions.text: Arden index is related to:
questions.solution:
Arden index is related to electro-oculography (EOG).

Arden index is the ratio of the light peak over the dark trough. A value above 185 is normal and below 150 is abnormal.

In electrooculography, electrodes are used to pick up changes in the resting ocular potential when the eyes are moved. These changes are recorded in accordance with changes in illumination. It indicates the activity of the pigmentary epithelium and the outer segments of visual receptors.

Other options:

Option A: Electroretinography measures changes in the resting potential of the eye, induced by stimulating the eye with light.

Option C: Specific alterations in an electroencephalogram (EEG) caused by visual stimuli are called as visual evoked responses (VER).

Option D: Perimetry is the measurement of a person’s field of vision.

questions.text: The electroretinogram (ERG) of a person is given below. In this ERG, wave B is due to?
questions.solution:
The image shown is a normal electroretinogram (ERG) in which wave B is due to Muller cells.

Electroretinography measures the changes in the resting potential of an eye, induced by the light stimulus. Waves of ERG include a,b and c. Among these, a and c are negative waves and b is a large positive wave as shown below. The c wave is only seen in the dark-adapted eye. 

Uses of ERG:

  • Diagnosis and prognosis of retinal disorders
  • Early detection of functional abnormalities of the outer retina up to the bipolar cell layer
  • Assessment of retinal function in babies with possible impaired vision and in cases where fundus examination is difficult (in the presence of dense cataracts and corneal opacity).
  • Focal ERG is used to evaluate the diseases of the macula.

Note: Diseases involving ganglion cell layer and higher visual pathways may show a normal ERG.

Abnormal ERG response:

  • Subnormal b-wave response is seen in early cases of retinitis pigmentosa.
  • Extinguished response is seen when there is a complete failure of rods and cones function e.g., advanced retinitis pigmentosa, complete retinal detachment, central retinal artery occlusion.
  • A negative response is seen in gross disturbances of the retinal circulation.

Match the following fundus fluorescein angiography findings with appropriate conditions:
1. Central serous chorioretinopathy a. Enlarged foveal avascular zone and capillary non-perfused areas
2. Cystoid macular edema b. Smokestack pattern
3. Macular Ischemia

c. Star in the sky appearance
4. Drusen d. Flower petal appearance
questions.solution:
The appropriate match for the given conditions is as follows:

Central serous chorioretinopathy Smokestack pattern
Cystoid macular edema Flower petal appearance
Macular Ischemia Enlarged foveal avascular zone and capillary non-perfused areas
Drusen   Star in the sky appearance

Central serous retinopathy is the spontaneous serous detachment of the macular region neurosensory retina with/without retinal pigment epithelium detachment. FFA shows two patterns of leakage, ink-blot pattern and smoke-stack pattern.

Cystoid macular oedema is defined as a collection of fluid between the outer plexiform (Henle's layer) and an inner nuclear layer of the retina. FFA shows a flower petal pattern (petaloid appearance).

In patients with macular ischemia, the FFA would show an enlarged foveal avascular zone arrow (white arrow), and capillary non-perfused areas (blue arrow)

questions.text:
Arrange the following photochemical changes of the visual cycle in the correct sequence:
  1. Scotopsin
  2. Lumirhodopsin
  3. Bathorhodopsin
  4. Metarhodopsin
questions.solution:
The correct sequence is 3-2-4-1. Bathorhodopsin → lumirhodopsin → metarhodopsin → scotopsin.

The image given below shows the visual cycle.

Rhodopsin is the visual pigment in the outer segment of rods responsible for scotopic vision (night/ dark vision). It consists of opsin and 11-cis retinal.

The process of separation of rhodopsin into opsin and all-trans-retinal on exposure to light is called photodecomposition (rhodopsin bleaching).

When light is absorbed by rhodopsin, it decomposes very quickly. This leads to an instantaneous change of the cis form of retinal into an all-trans form. This all-trans-retinal separates from scotopsin to produce bathorhodopsin. Bathorhodopsin is very unstable and decays to form lumirhodopsin, which then decays and forms metarhodopsin I, metarhodopsin II, and finally, into the completely split products scotopsin and all-trans-retinal. 

Metarhodopsin II is also called activated rhodopsin, and it produces excitatory changes in the rods, which transmits optic nerve action potentials. to the central nervous system.

Re-formation of rhodopsin involves the conversion of the all-trans-retinal back into 11-cis retinal. This requires metabolic energy and is catalyzed by retinal isomerase. 11-cis retinal then recombines with scotopsin to form rhodopsin. Rhodopsin now remains stable until it is triggered by light energy to start decomposing again.

The equilibrium between the photodecomposition and rhodopsin regeneration is referred to as the visual cycle.

Role of vitamin A: The second route of re-formation of rhodopsin involves the conversion of the all-trans-retinal into all-trans-retinol, which is a form of vitamin A. All-trans-retinol is converted into 11- cis retinol by isomerase. 11-cis retinol is then converted into 11-cis retinal, combines with scotopsin, and forms new rhodopsin.

questions.text: While performing a Purkinje image test in a patient having a mature cataract, you notice only 3 images.  Which of the following images are absent in this patient?

choices.text: Erect image formed by anterior surface of the lens
Erect image formed by posterior surface of the lens
Inverted image formed by anterior surface of the lens
Inverted image formed by posterior surface of the lens

questions.solution:
Image 4 i.e Inverted image formed by the Posterior surface of the lens is absent in patients with mature cataract.

Purkinje images are reflections of objects from the structure of the eye. They are also known as Purkinje reflexes or Purkinje–Sanson images.

Normal 4 images are formed from four different reflecting surfaces i.e.

  • Image 1—Anterior surface of the cornea: Erect
  • Image 2—Posterior surface of the cornea: Erect
  • Image 3—Anterior surface of the lens: Erect
  • Image 4—Posterior surface of the lens: Inverted
  • In aphakia: Image 3 and Image 4 are absent.

questions.text: A middle-aged man presented with foreign body sensation, irritation, and blurring of vision in his left eye for a few weeks. On examination, the finding as shown below is seen. Which of the following is the most effective treatment modality for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing a triangular fold of conjunctiva encroaching on the cornea from the nasal side are suggestive of pterygium. Conjunctival limbal autograft is the most effective treatment of pterygium.

In conjunctival limbal autografting, a piece of conjunctival tissue is taken from the limbus on the same side or from the other eye for grafting. This prevents recurrence. Autograft is retained with help of sutures or fibrin glue or with the patient's serum.

A pterygium is a degenerative and hyperplastic condition. The subconjunctival tissue undergoes elastotic degeneration and proliferates as vascularised tissue encroaching the cornea. It is a connective tissue disorder and is never inflammatory. It is most commonly seen on the nasal aspect of the eye.

It is predominantly seen in elder males who do outdoor work. UV radiation is one of the important risk factors. Patients may be asymptomatic or present with foreign body sensations, irritation, and defective vision. As they enlarge, it may obstruct vision and lead to astigmatism.

A fully developed pterygium has a head, neck, body, and cap. Deposition of iron as Stocker line may be seen on the corneal epithelium in front of the head of the pterygium.

Asymptomatic pterygium can be left alone. Patients with early-stage pterygia are advised to use protective eyewear. If it progresses towards the pupillary area and causes excessive astigmatism or a restriction of ocular motility or causes disfigurement, it should be treated by surgical excision.

Simple excision of the pterygium is associated with a high recurrence rate, and should be combined with:

  • Post-operative therapy with mitomycin C drops to prevent a recurrence. However, it may lead to complications like scleral necrosis, cataract, and iritis. 
  • Conjunctival limbal autografting
  • Amniotic membrane graft
  • Peripheral lamellar keratoplasty if the lesion is deep
  • Beta irradiation inhibits mitosis in the rapidly dividing cells of pterygium and can be used to prevent recurrences. However, it is not recommended because of its adverse effects which include scleral necrosis, endophthalmitis, and sectorial cataract formation.

questions.text: Which of the following charts and their respective uses are incorrectly paired?
questions.solution:
LogMAR charts are used for testing visual acuity, not for visual field defects.

LogMAR is an acronym for the base-10 logarithm of the minimum angle of resolution. It refers to the ability to resolve the elements of an optotype. It addresses many of the deficiencies of the Snellen chart, and is the standard means of VA measurement in research and increasingly in clinical practice.

Hess chart is used to diagnose and monitor patients with incomitant strabismus by assessing the field of a binocular single vision. In its interpretation, a smaller chart indicates the eye with the paretic muscle and a larger chart indicates the eye with an overacting muscle.

Incomitant strabismus is one where squint generally results from the limitation of eye movement associated with paralytic or mechanical etiologies like extraocular muscle palsy, thyroid ophthalmopathy, blow-out fracture, myasthenia gravis, etc. The field of binocular single vision is the area where bifoveal fusion of an object of interest occurs.

 

The Pelli-Robson contrast sensitivity letter chart consists of letters of constant size but decreasing contrast. It is viewed by the patient from a distance of 1 meter until the lowest resolvable group of three letters on the chart is reached. It is used to measure contrast sensitivity, a measure of the ability to distinguish an object against its background.

An image of the Pelli-Robson chart used in the Middle East is given below.

Jaeger’s chart is used to measure near vision. The smallest letter is designated as N5 or J1 and the largest as N48. It is held at a distance of 35 cm away from the patient. Snellen's near vision chart can also be used.

questions.text: A 72-year-old female presents with progressive central vision loss, distortion of straight lines, and difficulty reading. Fundoscopy reveals large drusens (>125 μm) in the macular area. What is the primary pathophysiological process responsible for the formation of these drusens?

choices.text: Accumulation of extracellular deposits between the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) and Bruch's membrane
Proliferation of fibrovascular tissue in the vitreous humor
Increased intraocular pressure causing retinal damage
Blockage of retinal blood vessels leading to ischemia

questions.solution:
This patient presents with features suggestive of age-related macular degeneration (AMD), a condition characterized by the accumulation of drusens between the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) and Bruch's membrane.

Symptoms like progressive central vision loss, distortion of straight lines (metamorphopsia), and difficulty reading, are classic signs of AMD. Drusens are yellowish-white deposits that disrupt the normal macular architecture, leading to progressive vision loss. In AMD, large drusens (>125 μm) are commonly observed on fundoscopy, as seen in this patient. Optical coherence tomography (OCT) further confirms the presence of hyperreflective irregular nodules between the RPE and Bruch's membrane, indicating the accumulation of these deposits.

Other Options:

Option B: Proliferation of fibrovascular tissue in vitreous humor: This process is not associated with drusen formation in AMD but may occur in conditions like proliferative diabetic retinopathy.

Option C: Increased intraocular pressure causing retinal damage: Describes the pathophysiology of glaucoma, not AMD.

Option D: Blockage of retinal blood vessels leading to ischemia: This is more relevant to conditions like diabetic retinopathy or retinal artery occlusion.

questions.text: A 51 year old female is diagnosed with central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO). Which of the following features would indicate ischemic CRVO over non-ischemic CRVO?

choices.text: Presence of relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD)

questions.solution:
Relative Afferent Pupillary Defect (RAPD) is a feature that is suggesive of ischmic CRVO. 

Ischemic central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) typically presents with acute and severe visual loss, marked retinal hemorrhages involving the entire fundus ("splashed tomato" appearance), cotton wool spots, optic disc edema, and the presence of a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD). RAPD indicates asymmetric function of the optic nerves, often due to ischemic damage in one eye.

Non-ischemic CRVO, on the other hand, generally manifests with milder symptoms such as venous congestion and tortuosity, superficial flame-shaped hemorrhages predominantly in the periphery, and mild macular edema. Fluorescein angiography in non-ischemic CRVO shows delayed A-V transit time and may demonstrate late leakage, indicating relatively preserved retinal perfusion compared to ischemic CRVO.

Other Options:

Option A: Venous congestion and tortuosity - While these features are common in both types of CRVO, severe venous congestion and tortuosity are more characteristic of ischemic CRVO.

Option B: Retinal hemorrhages - Extensive retinal hemorrhages involving the entire fundus are more typical of ischemic CRVO. Non-ischemic CRVO may present with superficial flame-shaped hemorrhages.

Option D: Sudden loss of vision - While sudden loss of vision can occur in both types of CRVO, it is not specific enough to distinguish between ischemic and non-ischemic types.

questions.text: A 58-year-old patient with a history of cardiovascular disease presents with sudden, painless loss of vision in one eye. Fundus examination reveals a pale retina with a cherry-red spot at the macula and segmentation of the blood column in the retinal veins. Which of the following steps can be taken within 24 hours to potentially improve the patient's outcome?

choices.text: Perform immediate paracentesis of the anterior chamber

questions.solution:
A 58-year-old patient with a history of cardiovascular disease presenting with sudden, painless loss of vision in one eye and a fundus examination showing a pale retina with a cherry-red spot is indicative of central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO). Immediate intervention to reduce IOP, including paracentesis of the anterior chamber, ocular massage or intravenous acetazolamide is critical to potentially improve the outcome.

Central retinal artery occlusion is a medical emergency where rapid restoration of blood flow is essential to prevent permanent vision loss. Paracentesis of the anterior chamber helps lower intraocular pressure, which can facilitate dislodging the embolus causing the occlusion. 

Other options:

Option A. Prescribe oral anticoagulants: Anticoagulants do not provide the immediate reduction in intraocular pressure or quick restoration of retinal blood flow necessary in acute CRAO.

Option C. Administer intravitreal steroids: Intravitreal steroids are used for inflammatory conditions and certain retinal disorders but are not effective in the acute management of CRAO.

Option D. Refer for retinal detachment surgery: Retinal detachment surgery is not relevant in the management of CRAO and requires immediate vascular intervention rather than surgical repair of retinal tissue.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with visual disturbances and is diagnosed with an intraocular tumor. Which type of retinal detachment is he most predisposed towards?
questions.solution:
Exudative retinal detachment occurs due to accumulation of fluid beneath the retina, often associated with neoplastic conditions like intraocular tumors. The tumor can disrupt the retinal architecture, leading to fluid leakage and separation from the underlying pigment epithelium.

In the context of an intraocular tumor, such as melanoma or retinoblastoma, the tumor itself or associated inflammation can disrupt the blood-retinal barrier, leading to the exudation of fluid into the subretinal space. This detachment typically presents as a smooth and dome-shaped elevation of the retina on clinical examination.

Other options:

Option A. Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment: This type is characterized by retinal breaks allowing fluid to seep under the retina. While trauma or degenerative changes can predispose to rhegmatogenous detachment, intraocular tumors are not typically associated with retinal breaks.

Option B. Tractional retinal detachment: This occurs due to mechanical traction on the retina, often seen in conditions like proliferative diabetic retinopathy or trauma, where fibrous bands pull the retina away from its normal position. Intraocular tumors do not typically exert mechanical traction leading to this type of detachment.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents with ptosis, miosis, and reduced sweating on the right side of the face. Which pharmacological test would be most appropriate to differentiate between pre-ganglionic and post-ganglionic lesions in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with Horner's syndrome. To differentiate between pre-ganglionic and post-ganglionic lesions, the hydroxyamphetamine test is used.

When hydroxyamphetamine (1%) is administered into the eye:

  • Pre-ganglionic Lesions: These lesions occur before the sympathetic nerves synapse at the superior cervical ganglion. In pre-ganglionic lesions, such as those affecting the sympathetic nerve fibres between the hypothalamus and the superior cervical ganglion, the ganglion itself, or the preganglionic fibers, the post-ganglionic sympathetic nerves beyond the ganglion remain intact. Therefore, when hydroxyamphetamine is administered:
  • Effect: The hydroxyamphetamine stimulates the release of norepinephrine from the intact post-ganglionic sympathetic nerve terminals.
  • Result: This leads to dilation of the pupil because the intact post-ganglionic nerves respond to the released norepinephrine, causing pupil dilation.

 

  • Post-ganglionic Lesions: These lesions occur beyond the superior cervical ganglion, affecting the sympathetic nerves travelling to the eye.
  • Effect: The sympathetic nerves beyond the ganglion are directly affected or damaged, impairing their ability to respond to hydroxyamphetamine-induced norepinephrine release
  • Result: As a consequence, there is no dilation of the pupil when hydroxyamphetamine is administered because the damaged post-ganglionic nerves cannot transmit the signal to dilate the pupil.

Other options:

Option B. Pilocarpine test: Pilocarpine induces pupil constriction by stimulating muscarinic receptors. It is used to diagnose conditions like Adie's tonic pupil, not Horner's syndrome.

Option C. Homatropine test: Homatropine is a muscarinic antagonist used to dilate the pupil for ocular examinations. It is not specific for diagnosing Horner's syndrome.

Option D. Tropicamide test: Tropicamide is another muscarinic antagonist used to dilate the pupil for diagnostic purposes. It is not specific for diagnosing Horner's syndrome.

Related Pearl: Horner's syndrome

Horner's Syndrome:

Horner's syndrome occurring due to occulo-sympathetic paresis is characterized by the classic triad of:

  • Mild ptosis (due to paralysis of Muller's muscle).
  • Miosis (due to paralysis of dilator pupillae).
  • Reduced ipsilateral sweating (anhydrosis).

Other features include:

  • Mild enophthalmos,
  • Loss of cilio-spinal reflex,
  • Heterochromia, i.e., the ipsilateral iris is lighter in colour,
  • Pupil is slow to dilate, and there occurs slight elevation of lower eyelid.

Cocaine test (2% to 4%): Small pupils fail to dilate in Horner's syndrome.

In congenital Horner's syndrome, the additional features seen are heterochromia iridis and unilateral straight hair.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient is diagnosed with a lesion in the visual cortex. Which of the following findings would you expect in this patient?

choices.text: Pupillary light reflex normal, optic disc atrophy present
Pupillary light reflex normal, optic disc atrophy absent
Pupillary light reflex abnormal, optic disc atrophy present
Pupillary light reflex abnormal, optic disc atrophy absent

questions.solution:
In a patient with a visual cortex lesion, Pupillary light reflex remains normal, while optic disc atrophy is absent. 

Patients with a lesion in the visual cortex typically present with specific clinical features related to their visual function. The visual cortex is crucial for interpreting visual information received from the eyes, and lesions here can lead to distinct visual deficits. Common findings include homonymous hemianopia, where there is loss of half of the visual field in both eyes, often sparing the central vision or macula. Additionally, visual hallucinations, impaired visual discrimination, and color vision disturbances may also be observed.

Pupillary light reflex: This reflex remains intact in patients with lesions restricted to the visual cortex. The pupillary response to light is normal because the pathway responsible for this reflex bypasses the visual cortex, involving the midbrain instead.

Optic disc atrophy: Optic disc atrophy is typically absent in lesions of the visual cortex. This is because the optic nerve fibers, which originate from retinal ganglion cells and form the optic disc, are not directly affected by lesions in the visual cortex.

questions.text:
Match the following clinical scenarios with the corresponding pupillary abnormality

 

  1. 55-year-old with an optic tract lesion with absent light reflex in the right temporal and left nasal visual fields but normal reflexes in the opposite fields.
  2. 40-year-old with an optic nerve lesion with paradoxical pupil dilation in response to light.
  3. 60-year-old with neurosyphilis with pupils that constrict to near objects but not to light.
  4. 30-year-old woman with unilateral dilated pupil that reacts slowly to light and shows a tonic near response

A. Marcus Gunn pupil
B. Wernicke's hemianopic pupil
C. Argyll Robertson pupil
D. Adie's tonic pupil
questions.solution:
The correct pairing is 1-B, 2-A, 3-C, 4-D

1. 55-year-old with an optic tract lesion with absent light reflex in the right temporal and left nasal visual fields but normal reflexes in the opposite fields: This pattern of pupillary response, known as Wernicke's hemianopic pupil, indicates a lesion in the optic tract. The absence of pupillary light reflex (both direct and consensual), when light is directed on specific retinal halves (temporal of affected eye, nasal of opposite eye), reflects the disruption in optic tract pathways. This finding is crucial for localizing the lesion along the visual pathway.

2. 40-year-old with an optic nerve lesion with paradoxical pupil dilation in response to light: This describes the Marcus Gunn pupil, where there is an abnormal pupillary response to light due to a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), typically caused by incomplete optic nerve lesions or severe retinal diseases. The affected pupil dilates instead of constricting when light is shone into it, as detected by the swinging flashlight test. It can be an early indicator of optic nerve disease despite preserved visual acuity.

3. 60-year-old with neurosyphilis with pupils that constrict to near objects but not to light: This scenario describes the Argyll Robertson pupil (ARP), which manifests as small, irregular pupils that react normally to near vision (accommodation reflex present) but do not constrict in response to light (light-near dissociation). ARP is typically associated with lesions in the tectal region of the midbrain, often due to neurosyphilis, and the pupils dilate poorly with mydriatics.

4. 30-year-old woman with unilateral dilated pupil that reacts slowly to light and shows a tonic near response: This condition is known as Adie's tonic pupil, characterized by unilateral pupil dilation (anisocoria), slow pupillary light response, and a tonic constriction during near reflex testing. Adie's pupil is caused by post-ganglionic parasympathetic damage, often associated with absent knee jerk reflex and more prevalent in young women. It exhibits supersensitivity to weak pilocarpine drops due to denervation hypersensitivity of the iris sphincter.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is not part of the accommodation reflex pathway?
questions.solution:
The inferior colliculus is part of the auditory pathway and is not involved in the accommodation reflex pathway.

The pathway of the accommodation reflex involves the following structures:

  • Afferent Pathway: Impulses extend from the retina to the parastriate cortex via the optic nerve, chiasma, optic tract, lateral geniculate body, and striate cortex.
  • Relay: From the parastriate cortex, impulses are relayed to the Edinger-Westphal nucleus of both sides via the occipitomesencephalic tract and the pontine center.
  • Efferent Pathway: From the Edinger-Westphal nucleus, efferent impulses travel along the 3rd nerve and reach the sphincter pupillae and ciliary muscle after relaying in the accessory and ciliary ganglions.

questions.text: Which of the following  is NOT suggestive of an early glaucomatous change in the optic disc?

choices.text: Vertically oval cup due to selective loss of neural rim tissue in the inferior and superior poles
Large cup, with a cup:disc ratio of 0.5
Splinter haemorrhages present on or near the optic disc margin

questions.solution:
Thinning of the neuro-retinal rim (NRR) is indicative of advanced glaucomatous changes, not early ones. This distinguishes it from other early signs such as vertically oval cup and splinter hemorrhages.

Glaucomatous changes in the optic disc can be classified into early changes, advanced changes, and glaucomatous optic atrophy.

Early glaucomatous changes should be suspected if fundus examination reveals one or more of the following signs:

  • Vertically oval cup due to selective loss of neural rim tissue in the inferior and superior poles: This change indicates a loss of nerve fibers in these areas, causing the optic cup to appear more vertically elongated.
  • Asymmetry of the cups: A difference of more than 0.2 between the two eyes is significant and suggests glaucomatous damage.
  • Large cup, with a cup: disc ratio greater than 0.4: Normal cup size ranges from 0.3 to 0.4, and an increased cup-to-disc ratio suggests a loss of optic nerve fibers.
  • Splinter hemorrhages present on or near the optic disc margin: These small, flame-shaped hemorrhages around the optic disc indicate glaucomatous damage.
  • Pallor areas on the disc: Pallor suggests a loss of nerve fibers and is associated with glaucomatous damage.
  • Atrophy of the retinal nerve fiber layer (RNFL): This can be seen with red-free light and indicates the loss of the optic nerve fibers.
  • RNFL defects appear as wedge-shaped dark areas arising from the optic nerve head: These defects are early indicators of glaucomatous damage.

Advanced glaucomatous changes in the optic disc include:

  • Marked cupping (cup size 0.7 to 0.9): Excavation may reach the disc margin, and the sides are steep and not shelving. This is well-delineated on OCT examination.
  • Thinning of the neuro-retinal rim (NRR): Seen as a crescentric shadow adjacent to the disc margin, thinning of the NRR occurs in advanced cases and indicates significant optic nerve damage.

Glaucomatous optic atrophy: As the damage progresses, all the neural tissue of the disc is destroyed, and the optic nerve head appears white and deeply excavated. This represents the final stage of glaucomatous damage.

questions.text:
Which among the following secondary glaucomas result in open-angle glaucoma?
  1. Phacomorphic Glaucoma
  2. Phacolytic Glaucoma
  3. Lens Particle Glaucoma
questions.solution:
Phacolytic Glaucoma and Lens Particle Glaucoma are both types of secondary glaucomas that present with open-angle pathology. In contrast, Phacomorphic Glaucoma presents with acute angle-closure glaucoma.

Phacomorphic Glaucoma: This condition results from an intumescent lens pushing the iris forward and causing secondary acute angle closure glaucoma. It presents with features similar to acute primary angle-closure glaucoma but with a swollen cataractous lens.

Phacolytic Glaucoma (Lens Protein Glaucoma): This type of secondary open-angle glaucoma occurs due to leakage of lens proteins through a hypermature cataract. The trabecular meshwork gets obstructed by these proteins and inflammatory debris, causing an acute rise in IOP.

Lens Particle Glaucoma: In this condition, trabecular meshwork is blocked by lens particles floating in the aqueous humor. It can occur after accidental or planned extracapsular cataract extraction or lens trauma, leading to symptoms of acute rise in IOP.

Therefore, Phacomorphic Glaucoma  is specifically associated with acute angle closure due to an intumescent lens, while the others describe different forms of secondary open-angle glaucomas resulting from lens protein leakage and lens particle obstruction, respectively.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient with a history of open-angle glaucoma is prescribed a new medication. After a few weeks of treatment, the patient reports experiencing unusual sensations in his hands and feet, described as tingling or "pins and needles." Which of the following drugs was he most likely started on?
questions.solution:
The patient was most likely started on acetazolamide, which explains the paresthesia (tingling sensations) he is experiencing. Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor used to decrease aqueous humor production in the treatment of glaucoma. 

Acetazolamide can cause a range of side effects:

  • Paresthesias: Tingling sensations in the fingers, toes, hands, feet, and around the mouth. These are transient and typically harmless.
  • Urinary Frequency: Increased urination due to the drug's diuretic effect.
  • Bicarbonate depletion: Leading to metabolic acidosis and symptoms like malaise, fatigue, depression, loss of libido, anorexia, and weight loss. Sodium bicarbonate or sodium acetate can help manage these symptoms.

Other side effects include Gastrointestinal Symptoms like vague abdominal discomfort, gastric irritation, nausea, metallic taste, and diarrhea, as well as Sulfonamide-Related Side Effects

Other options:-

Option B. Latanoprost, a prostaglandin analog, increases the outflow of aqueous humor and can cause side effects such as conjunctival hyperemia (eye redness), foreign body sensation, and increased pigmentation of the iris.

Option C. Timolol is a beta-blocker that reduces aqueous humor production, with side effects including ocular burning, conjunctival hyperemia, and systemic effects like bradycardia, bronchospasm, and depression.

Option D. Pilocarpine, a muscarinic agonist, enhances aqueous humor outflow and may cause bradycardia, increased sweating, diarrhea, excessive salivation, and local effects like miosis-related visual issues and spasm of accommodation.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman complains of discomfort in her left eye. There is a past history of blunt trauma in her childhood which made her left eye blind. Slit-lamp examination of her left eye is shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
These are synchysis scintillans, which are floaters composed of cholesterol bodies, found in the vitreous (extending into the anterior chamber in this picture).

Synchysis scintillans are vitreous opacities that occur as a consequence of chronic vitreous haemorrhage, often in a blind eye. This condition is usually discovered, when frank haemorrhage is no longer present. They are composed of cholesterol derived from plasma cells or degraded products of erythrocytes.

Vitreous opacities:

They can be caused by a variety of pathological processes and the following are few examples of vitreous opacities

  • Muscae volitantes

questions.text:
Which among the following are based on applanation tonometry?

1. Goldmann tonometer

2. Tono-Pen

3. Perkins tonometer

4. Pneumatic tonometer
questions.solution:
Goldmann tonometer, tono-pen, Perkin's applanation tonometry, and pneumatic tonometer are all based on the principle of applanation tonometry. 

Tonometers are used to measure intraocular pressure. There are two types of tonometers. They are indentation and applanation tonometers.

Applanation tonometry is more accurate. The applanation tonometer measures the amount of force needed to applanate (flatten) a known corneal area based on the Imbert-Fick law. Goldmann tonometer, Tono-Pen, pneumatic tonometer, and Perkin's applanation tonometry uses the principle of applanation.

Indentation tonometry is based on the principle that a plunger will indent more on a soft eye than a hard eye. Schiotz tonometer is the most widely used tonometer as it is cheap and hand-held. However, it can give false readings if used in an eye with abnormal scleral rigidity.

questions.text: A teenager comes with complaints of difficulty in seeing far away objects. You assess him using Snellen's chart. The maximum he is able to read with his left eye, at a distance of 6 meters, is the 18 meter line. What is his left eye vision recorded to be?
questions.solution:
His vision would be recorded as 6/18.

Snellen's chart is used to evaluate a patient's visual acuity. The visual acuity is recorded as a fraction with the numerator being the distance of the patient from the chart and the denominator being the smallest line of letters that is accurately read.

Here, the teenager is sitting at a distance of 6 meters from the chart (numerator) and the smallest line of letters he is able to read is the 18-meter line (denominator). Thus, the vision recorded would be 6/18. 

Visual acuity is the measurement of the eye's ability to discriminate between two points. Visual acuity tests such as Snellen's contain a series of letters that are arranged in lines, and each line has progressively decreasing sizes of letters. 

Each letter of the chart is designed to fit in a square, the sides of which are five times the breadth of the constituent line. At a given distance, each letter subtends an angle of 5 min at the eye's nodal point. 

The letters on the line at the top of Snellen's chart should be read clearly at a distance of 60 meters. Each subsequent line is read at 36, 24, 18, 12, 9, 6, and 5 meters, respectively. 

Testing is done by seating the patient at a distance of 6meters from Snellen's chart (at this distance the rays of light are almost parallel and the patient exerts minimum accommodation). Then the patient is asked to read the chart with each eye separately and the results are recorded.

questions.text: An ophthalmology resident while presenting the seminar on staphyloma presents the following image showing different types of staphyloma. The type of staphyloma occurring at point A, at the limbus, is known as :
questions.solution:
The type of staphyloma occurring at point A is known as intercalary staphyloma. It is located at the limbus and is lined by the root of the iris and the anterior-most part of the ciliary body.

The patient usually has defective vision due to marked corneal astigmatism. The treatment consists of localised staphylectomy under heavy doses of oral steroids.

In the above image:

A: Intercalary staphyloma
B: Ciliary staphyloma
C: Equatorial staphyloma
D: Posterior staphyloma

Staphyloma:

It is an abnormal protrusion of the uveal tissue through a weak and thin portion of the cornea or sclera.

  • It is lined internally by uveal tissue and externally by weak cornea or sclera.
  • Types of Staphyloma:
    • Anterior staphyloma: It is characterized by ectasia of the pseudo-cornea, which occurs after the total sloughing of the cornea. It is lined internally by the iris and externally by the newly formed epithelium.
    • Intercalary staphyloma: This is located at the limbus and is lined by the root of the iris and the anterior-most part of the ciliary body
    • Ciliary staphyloma: It is characterized by ectasia of weak sclera lined by the ciliary body. This affects the ciliary zone, which includes the region up to 8 mm behind the limbus.
    • Equatorial staphyloma: This occurs at the equatorial region up to 14 mm behind the limbus of the eye.
    • Posterior staphyloma: This affects the posterior pole of the eye.
  • Note :
    • The most common cause of anterior staphyloma is a sloughing corneal ulcer.
    • The most common cause of posterior staphyloma is degenerative high axial myopia.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presented with worsening night blindness for the last few years. On further questioning, he reveals that he has been having increasing difficulty doing daily activities like reading and walking without bumping into objects. His fundoscopy findings are shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with a clinical picture of worsening night blindness, difficulty in walking and reading, with fundoscopic features (bone spicule changes, retinal atrophy, and a peripheral ring of depigmentation) is likely to have retinitis pigmentosa.

Retinitis pigmentosa is retinal dystrophy that results in retinal rod and cone degeneration. It can be inherited (autosomal dominant, autosomal recessive, or X-linked recessive) or acquired due to sporadic mutation in the rhodopsin gene. 

Patients present with worsening night blindness. However, patients do not often notice night blindness and may present after much disease progression. They also develop tunnel vision, which manifests as difficulty performing activities of daily living such as reading, walking, and driving. 

Ocular examination reveals normal visual activity and central vision (though central vision will be involved later in disease progression). Fundoscopy shows bilateral, mid-peripheral intraretinal perivascular 'bone-spicule' changes and atrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium. There is severe peripheral pigmentation, arteriolar narrowing, and pallor of the disc. 

Retinitis pigmentosa can lead to posterior subcapsular cataracts, open-angle glaucoma, keratoconus, and posterior vitreous detachment as possible complications. 

There is no specific treatment for retinitis pigmentosa. Some interventions that may help include the following: 

  • Regular follow-up to assess vision and provide low-vision aid, rehabilitation, and social services
  • Cataract surgery
  • 'Nanometer controlled' sunglasses as light protective strategies for outdoor and indoor use
  • Avoidance of retinotoxic medications

Other options:

Option B: Vitamin A deficiency would lead to xerophthalmia. This also has night blindness and loss of vision. However, retinal involvement would be characterized by yellowish, peripheral dots in advanced cases. 

Option C: Retinal detachment occurs when there is a separation between the neuroepithelium and pigment epithelium of the retina. This can occur due to trauma, neoplasm, or fluid accumulation. It is characterized by light flashes, floaters, and a 'curtain' obscuring the vision. Ophthalmoscopy features depend on the stage. Early stages may not be apparent other than color changes, but later stages may show folds that oscillate on eye movement, grey depressions, and bright summits. 

The image given below shows a shifting fluid sign in exudative retinal detachment.

The following image shows central retinal detachment.

Option D: Acquired syphilis is characterized by anterior uveitis, chorioretinitis, and posterior placoid chorioretinopathy. The retina will have a ground-glass appearance and have vasculitis, leading to scars.

Related Pearl: WHO grading of Vitamin A deficiency

The term xerophthalmia is reserved to cover all the ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency.

X1A Conjunctival Xerosis Conjunctival epithelial alteration, loss of goblet cells
X1B Bitot’s spots Conjunctival keratinization and plaque formation
X2 Corneal xerosis Corneal epithelial alteration
X3A Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting <1/3rd of the corneal surface Liquefaction of corneal stroma
X3B Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting >1/3rd of the corneal surface              -
XS Corneal scar              -
XF Xerophthalmic fundus Degeneration of the retinal pigment epithelium

 

The first symptom of xerophthalmia is nyctalopia.

The first sign of xerophthalmia is conjunctival xerosis.

The pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia is the appearance of Bitot's spots.

Note:

Up to Stage X2, the manifestations are reversible if treated with vitamin A supplements. Active conjunctival xerosis and Bitot’s spots begin to resolve within 2—5 days after supplementation. Most will disappear within 2 weeks, although a significant proportion of temporal lesions may persist in shrunken form and may therefore not be completely reversible.

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic woman presents to you with complaints of a decrease in vision in the left eye. There is also a history of cataract surgery 1 month back on the same eye. Investigation reveals flower petal pattern on fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA). Optical coherence tomography done in this patient is shown in the image below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and OCT image showing cystic spaces are suggestive of cystoid macular edema (CME) in a patient with a history of cataract surgery points towards the diagnosis of Irvine-Gass syndrome.

Optical coherence tomography (OCT) in CME reveals loss of foveal depression, intraretinal area of decreased reflectivity with round optically clear regions (cystoid spaces)

Irvine-Gass syndrome is the late postoperative complications of cataract surgery. The characteristic flower-petal appearance is due to the accumulation of dye in the outer plexiform layer at the fovea. CME occurs due to a break in the inner and outer blood-retinal barrier.

Ophthalmoscopy reveals loss of foveal contour, retinal thickening, a yellow spot at the center of the fovea, and Honeycomb appearance of the macula is seen due to multiple cystoid oval spaces.

 

Few other late postoperative complications of cataract surgery include,

  • Delayed chronic postoperative endophthalmitis
  • Pseudophakic bullous keratopathy
  • Retinal detachment
  • After cataract or secondary cataract

Note: Central serous retinopathy (CSR) shows fluid accumulation in the subretinal space due to abnormal permeability of the choriocapillaris. Fundus fluorescein angiography may demonstrate an enlarging inkblot pattern or smoke stack pattern. The OCT image showing fluid in the subretinal space is given below.

questions.text: A person sustained an injury to the right eye with a tennis ball, following which he developed pain. On fundus examination, a milky white macula with a red spot is seen. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Commotio retinae, or Berlin’s edema, is the most probable diagnosis.

It occurs following a blow to the eye. It manifests as milky white cloudiness involving a considerable area of the posterior pole with a ‘cherry-red spot’ in the foveal region.

Blunt trauma to the eye produces:

  • Vossius ring - It is a circular ring of brown pigment seen on the anterior capsule. It occurs due to the striking of the contracted pupillary margin against the crystalline lens.
  • Rosette cataract - It is the most typical form of concussion cataract.
  • Commotio retinae (Berlin’s edema) - It manifests as milky white cloudiness involving a considerable area of the posterior pole with a "cherry-red spot" at the foveola.

It may disappear after some days or may be followed by pigmentary changes. Given below is an image of Berlin's edema.

questions.text:
Which of the following are true regarding the intraocular lens given below:
  1. It is designed to be placed in the posterior chamber
  2. It is designed to be placed in the anterior chamber
  3. The most ideal method of fixation is in the capsular bag
  4. Scleral fixation is the best-advised method of fixation
  5. Also called Singh and Worst's lens
questions.solution:
The above image depicts a modified C-loop type of posterior chamber intraocular lens (PCIOL).

The central part overlying the optic axis is called the optic. The peripheral arms used for placement and stabilization are the haptics.

Posterior Chamber IOL:

  • The IOL is best placed in the posterior chamber.
  • PCIOLs rest entirely behind the iris.
  • They may be supported and fixed as
    • Capsular bag fixation of PCIOL (most ideal method)
    • Ciliary sulcus fixation
    • Sclera fixation

Anterior Chamber IOL:

  • Lie entirely in front of the iris and are supported in the angle of the anterior chamber
  • Are associated with a higher incidence of bullous keratopathy
  • Kelman multiflex type of anterior chamber intraocular lens (ACIOL) is the most commonly used ACIOL (image below)

Singh and Worst’s is a type of iris-claw lens.

  • The iris-supported lens is fixed with the help of sutures, loops, or claws.
  • These lenses are associated with a high incidence of postoperative complications.

questions.text: A patient underwent a trabeculectomy, following which he developed a headache. Examination revealed that the anterior chamber was flat, the Seidel test result was negative, and the intraocular pressure was raised. He was given 1% atropine, which improved his condition. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on clinical features is malignant glaucoma.

Malignant glaucoma is seen after intraocular surgery such as trabeculectomy. The forward flow of aqueous is blocked as the tips of ciliary processes rotate forward and press against the lens/IOL/anterior hyaloid of the vitreous. Hence, aqueous humor collects in the vitreous cavity.

Clinical features:

  • Persistent shallow or flat anterior chamber
  • Negative Seidel’s test result
  • Raised intra-ocular pressure

Treatment

  • Atropine:
    • Malignant glaucoma is also called inverse glaucoma since atropine is used.
    • It dilates the ciliary ring and increases the distance between the ciliary processes and the equator of the lens, thereby tightening the zonule and pulling the lens posteriorly into its normal position.
  • Intravenous mannitol may be used if mydriatics are ineffective, in order to shrink the vitreous gel and allow the lens to move posteriorly.
  • Nd:YAG laser hyaloidotomy - making an opening in the anterior hyaloid membrane
  • Pars plana vitrectomy

Other options:

Option A: Posner–Schlossman syndrome is characterized by recurrent attacks of unilateral acute raised intraocular pressure associated with mild anterior uveitis. It presents with mild discomfort, haloes, and blurring of vision.

Option B: Pseudoexfoliation glaucoma is rapidly progressive and can lead to significant visual loss. It is an ocular manifestation of a systemic condition in which pseudoexfoliative material is deposited on structures like the lens capsule, zonular fibers, iris, trabeculae, and conjunctiva.

Option C: Phacolytic glaucoma is a secondary open-angle glaucoma associated with a hypermature cataract. Patients present with pain and poor vision. Slit-lamp examination shows corneal edema, hypermature cataract, and deep anterior chamber. Large, floating, white particles consisting of lens protein and protein-containing macrophages may be seen in the anterior chamber.

questions.text: All of the following ocular findings are associated with Dorsal-Midbrain (Parinaud's) syndrome, except

choices.text: Paresis of downward gaze with preserved upward gaze

questions.solution:
Parinaud's syndrome refers to supranuclear vertical gaze disorder. Here there is a loss of up-gaze and the downward gaze is usually preserved.

Parinaud's syndrome/dorsal midbrain syndrome is caused by damage to the posterior commissure. Classically, signs of hydrocephalus are seen due to aqueductal stenosis.

Causes:

  • Pineal region or midbrain tumors (most common cause)
  • Neurocysticercosis
  • Stroke
  • Multiple sclerosis

Features include the following:

  • Loss of up-gaze (downward gaze is usually preserved)
  • Convergence–retraction nystagmus on attempted upgaze
  • Downward ocular deviation- Setting-sun sign
  • Lid retraction- Collier's sign
  • Pseudo-Argyll–Robertson pupil- Accommodative paresis ensues and pupils become mid-dilated and show light-near dissociation
  • Bilateral papilledema
  • Skew deviation
  • Pseudoabducens palsy

questions.text: A patient presents with pain, photophobia, and lacrimation. On slit lamp examination, keratic precipitates are seen. You prescribe 1% atropine sulfate eye drops for iridocyclitis and advise regarding the application. Which of the following is false regarding the steps of application of the eyedrops?

choices.text: Pull the lower eyelid down to create a pocket for the drops
After administration, apply gentle pressure to the tear duct for a minute
Blink immediately after applying the eye drops
The head must be tilted backward during application

questions.solution:
Proper administration of eye drops is crucial to ensure their effectiveness. Blinking immediately after applying the eye drops can cause the drops to be expelled from the eye, reducing their efficacy.

Steps to administer eye drops:

  1. Tilt your head back and look up
  2. With 1 hand, pull your lower eyelid down and away from your eyeball — this makes a “pocket” for the drops
  3. With the other hand, hold the eye drop bottle upside down with the tip just above the pocket
  4. Squeeze the prescribed number of eye drops into the pocket
  5. For at least 1 minute, close your eye and press your finger lightly on your tear duct (small hole in the inner corner of your eye) — this keeps the eye drop from draining into your nose

Precautions:

  • Wash your hands with soap and water before you use eye drops
  • Don’t touch the tip of the eye drop bottle with your hands
  • Don’t let the tip of the eye drop bottle touch your eye or eyelid

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman who has been complaining of unilateral headache and jaw pain for 2 weeks, now comes with complaints of blurry vision. She also has a history of stiffness and pain in her shoulders and hips. Visual field examination shows a pale optic disc. questions.solution:
This patient's clinical picture is suggestive of giant cell arteritis (GCA) with polymyalgia rheumatica which is most commonly associated with anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AION).

AION is due to the interference in the circulation of the posterior ciliary artery supplying the anterior part of the optic nerve.

Anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AION):

The two types are as follows:

In GCA with visual changes, corticosteroid therapy should be started as soon as possible. An intravenous loading dose of 200 mg hydrocortisone or 500 mg methylprednisolone administered slowly over one hour is recommended. It is followed by high doses of oral prednisolone (1 mg/kg/day) given daily for the first week. A maintenance dose of 5–15 mg is continued for at least 6–12 months.

Other Options: 

Option A: Central retinal artery occlusion presents as a sudden painless loss of vision. It is most often caused due to an embolus from an atherosclerotic plaque. Fundus examination shows an opaque, milky-white retina with a cherry-red spot as shown below.

Option C: Central retinal vein occlusion also causes painless loss of vision, although not as rapidly as CRAO. Fundoscopy demonstrates tortuous engorged veins and retinal hemorrhages as shown below.

Option D: Posterior ischemic optic neuropathy involves the small pial vessels supplying the intraorbital portion of the optic nerve. Although it is associated with vasculitides like giant cell arteritis and systemic lupus erythematosus, it doesn't affect the fundus. There is no edema or hemorrhage on fundoscopy.

questions.text: A Schirmer’s test was performed on a woman who presented with chronic irritation and dryness in both eyes. What is incorrect regarding the procedure done?

choices.text: The strip is placed at the junction of medial 2/3rd and lateral 1/3rd of the lower eyelid
The strip is removed after 5 minutes and the wet portion is measured
Strip wetting of less than 10 mm is indicative of aqueous tear deficiency
A tear-film break up time (TBUT) of less than 30 seconds is suggestive of dry eye

questions.solution:
The incorrect statement regarding the Schirmer’s test is that the tear-film break-up time (TBUT) of less than 10 seconds is suggestive of dry eye (Option D) since this finding is seen in a slit-lamp study following 1% sodium fluorescein staining.        

The time taken for the first appearance of a ‘dark’ dry spot after the patient blinks is recorded as the ‘tear-film break-up time’ (‘TBUT’). A TBUT of less than 10 seconds is suggestive of a dry eye with a deficiency of mucin. 

The Schirmer test is performed by folding 5 mm at the top end of a special Schirmer test filter paper strip and placing it in the lower conjunctival sac of the open eye (Option A). It is placed at the junction of the outer one-third and medial two-thirds of the lower lid, and left in place for 5 minutes or until 30 mm of the strip becomes wet (Option B).

If tear fluid fails to diffuse over the lid margin along the strip within 2 minutes, it is removed to another site within the sac for another 5 minutes. The strip is then removed from the eye after 5 minutes and the wet portion is measured. Wetting of less than 10 mm is indicative of an aqueous tear deficiency (Option C).
